newsitem.title: USA: Analysts, traders hail CVRD auction.
newsitem.headline: Analysts, traders hail CVRD auction.

text.p: Brazil's auction of state-run mining giant Companhia Vale do Rio Doce (CVRD) is a milestone for economic reform in Latin America's biggest country, analysts and traders said Wednesday.

The sale of 41.7 percent of the company Tuesday to a consortium, headed by Brazilian steel maker Companhia Siderurgica Nacional and financed by NationsBank and other financial institutions, also set the stage for auction of other state firms.
"It means one big thing is out of the way and they can focus on reforms and privatization," said Lucia Skwarek, head of Latin American equities at UBS Securities.
"It is enormously important for the market -- it sets a really good tone for the rest of the year."
ING Barings analyst Mirela Rappaport called the sale "a landmark in Brazil's economic history."
"By transferring CVRD to the private sector, Brazil sends the world an important message regarding its commitment to economic liberalization and modernization," she wrote in a report.

The reformist administration of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso sold the controlling stake in CVRD, the world's biggest iron ore exporter, for $3.12 billion. The privatization was the largest in Latin American history.
The government battled a wave of court orders and years of opposition to sell the stake in CVRD, considered the crown jewel in Brazil's huge state-run sector.
The final price was 20 percent above the minimum bid. However, CVRD preferred shares fell 6.47 percent to 26 reais in Sao Paulo amid profit-taking and some disappointment the premium was not higher.
Mariana Albuquerque, Latin American economist at Lehman Brothers, said the auction was a tremendous boost for privatization of state-run electric companies and telephone company Telebras SA.
Those sales could start late this year or in 1998.
"It just builds momentum for the ... privatizations that Cardoso has on the agenda, including telecommunications," she said.
Alburquerque added that the CVRD sale could mean opponents would fight even harder to block the sale of Telebras.
However, "as far as foreign investors are concerned, they will realize that (Brazil's) is a serious government and it is ready to deal with that kind of opposition," she said.
The sale also converts CSN, the head of the winning consortium, into one of the most powerful natural resources companies in Latin America, Morgan Stanley analysts Hillary Peruzzi said.
CSN, already the biggest steel producer in Latin America, will have major holdings in ore, gold, aluminum, transportation, steel and pulp and paper through the CVRD stake.
"CVRD was already a world leader in mining and metal production and CSN was already Latin America's biggest steel company," she said.
"Now they are a very power company with a lot of holdings over Latin American natural resources."
Through CVRD minority stakes, CSN will have pieces of almost all the other big Brazilian steel companies, including Companhia Siderurgica de Tubarao, Acominas, Usiminas and Cosipa.
CVRD faces two more phases of privatization. The government will sell a five percent stake to company employees and will carry out a public offering of its remaining holdings.
